sn56.40:4.1: “Mendicants, take any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn56.40:4.2: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking:
sn56.40:4.3: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s just not possible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
sn56.40:5.1: Suppose there was a stone pillar, sixteen feet long.
sn56.40:5.2: Eight feet were buried underground, and eight above ground.
sn56.40:5.3: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south,
sn56.40:5.6: they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.
sn56.40:5.8: It’s because that boundary pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.
sn56.40:5.9: In the same way, take any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn56.40:5.11: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s just not possible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
sn56.40:5.19: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.
sn56.40:5.21: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.40:6.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
